whistle.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to make a high or musical sound by blowing air out through your lips
whistle.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: Adam whistled happily on his way to work.
I heard this song on the radio and Iâ€™ve been whistling it all day.
He whistled a tune as he strolled down the corridor.
Dad whistled to us to come home for dinner.
Men are always whistling at Heidi on the street.
whistle.translation[0].definitions[1].de: to make a high sound by blowing into a whistle
whistle.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: The referee whistled and the game began.
whistle.translation[0].definitions[2].de: to move quickly, making a whistling sound
whistle.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: Bullets and shells were whistling overhead.
They listened to the wind whistling through the trees.
whistle.translation[0].definitions[3].de: if a steam train or kettle whistles, it makes a high sound when air or steam is forced through a small hole
whistle.translation[0].definitions[4].de: if a bird whistles, it makes a high musical sound
whistle.translation[1].definitions[0].de: a small object that produces a high whistling sound when you blow into it
whistle.translation[1].definitions[1].de: a high sound made by blowing a whistle, by blowing air out through your lips, or when air or steam is forced through a small opening
whistle.translation[1].definitions[1].ex: Larsson scored just minutes before the final whistle.
Sanders gave a low whistle when he saw the contents of the box.
whistle.translation[1].definitions[2].de: a piece of equipment on a train or boat that makes a high noise when air is forced through it
whistle.translation[1].definitions[3].de: the sound of something moving quickly through the air
whistle.translation[1].definitions[3].ex: We could hear the whistle of the jets as they passed overhead.
